title: Egypt–United Kingdom relations
text:
Egypt–United Kingdom relations refers to the <a href="bilateralism">bilateral relationship</a> between <a href="Arab%20Republic%20of%20Egypt">Egypt</a> and <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20Northern%20Ireland">Great Britain</a>. Relations are longstanding. They involve politics, defence, trade and education, as well as issues regarding the Suez Canal.
History.
British rule.
The first period of British rule (1882–1914) was the "veiled protectorate". During this time the <a href="Khedivate%20of%20Egypt">Khedivate of Egypt</a> remained an autonomous province of the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. In reality the British made all the decisions and thus had a "de facto" protectorate over the country. This state of affairs lasted until the Ottoman Empire joined the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> on the side of the <a href="Central%20Powers">Central Powers</a> in November 1914 and Britain unilaterally declared a protectorate over Egypt. The Ottomans thereby lost all connections. The ruling khedive was deposed and his successor, <a href="Hussein%20Kamel%20of%20Egypt">Hussein Kamel</a>, was compelled to declare himself <a href="Sultanate%20of%20Egypt">Sultan of Egypt</a> independent of the Ottomans in December 1914.
Seizure of Egypt, 1882.
As owners of the Suez Canal, both British and French governments had strong interests in the stability of Egypt. Most of the traffic was by British merchant ships. However, in 1881 the <a href="%CA%BBUrabi%20revolt">ʻUrabi revolt</a> broke out-- it was a nationalist movement led by <a href="Ahmed%20%CA%BBUrabi">Ahmed ʻUrabi</a> (1841–1911) against the administration of <a href="Khedive">Khedive</a> <a href="Tewfik%20Pasha">Tewfik</a>, who collaborated closely with the British and French. Combined with the complete turmoil in Egyptian finances, the threat to the Suez Canal, and embarrassment to British prestige if it could not handle a revolt, London found the situation intolerable and decided to end it by force. The French, however, did not join in. On 11 July 1882, Gladstone ordered the <a href="bombardment%20of%20Alexandria">bombardment of Alexandria</a> which launched the short decisive <a href="1882%20Anglo-Egyptian%20War">short, Anglo-Egyptian War of 1882</a>. Egypt nominally remained under the sovereignty of the Ottoman Empire, and France and other nations had representation, but British officials made the decisions. The dominant personality was <a href="Evelyn%20Baring%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Cromer">Evelyn Baring, 1st Earl of Cromer</a>. He was thoroughly familiar with the British Raj in India, and applied similar policies to take full control of the Egyptian economy. London 66 times promised to depart in a few years; the actual result was British control of Egypt for four decades, largely ignoring the Ottoman Empire.
Historian <a href="A.J.P.%20Taylor">A.J.P. Taylor</a> says that the seizure of Egypt "was a great event; indeed, the only real event in international relations between the Battle of Sedan and the defeat of Russia in the Russo-Japanese war."
Taylor emphasizes long-term impact:
Gladstone and the Liberals had a reputation for strong opposition to imperialism, so historians have long debated the explanation for this reversal of policy. The most influential was a study by John Robinson and Ronald Gallagher, "<a href="Africa%20and%20the%20Victorians">Africa and the Victorians</a>" (1961). They focused on <a href="The%20Imperialism%20of%20Free%20Trade">The Imperialism of Free Trade</a> and promoted the highly influential <a href="Cambridge%20School%20of%20historiography">Cambridge School of historiography</a>. They argue there was no long-term Liberal plan in support of imperialism. Instead they saw the urgent necessity to act to protect the Suez Canal in the face of what appeared to be a radical collapse of law and order, and a nationalist revolt focused on expelling the Europeans, regardless of the damage it would do to international trade and the British Empire. Gladstone's decision came against strained relations with France, and maneuvering by "men on the spot" in Egypt. Critics such as Cain and Hopkins have stressed the need to protect large sums invested by British financiers and Egyptian bonds, while downplaying the risk to the viability of the Suez Canal. Unlike the Marxists, they stress "gentlemanly" financial and commercial interests, not the industrial capitalism that Marxists believe was always central.
A.G. Hopkins rejected Robinson and Gallagher's argument, citing original documents to claim that there was no perceived danger to the Suez Canal from the ‘Urabi movement, and that ‘Urabi and his forces were not chaotic "anarchists", but rather maintained law and order. He alternatively argues that Gladstone's cabinet was motivated by protecting the interests of British bondholders with investments in Egypt as well as by pursuit of domestic political popularity. Hopkins cites the British investments in Egypt that grew massively leading into the 1880s, partially as a result of the Khedive's debt from construction of the Suez Canal, as well as the close links that existed between the British government and the economic sector. He writes that Britain's economic interests occurred simultaneously with a desire within one element of the ruling Liberal Party for a militant foreign policy in order to gain the domestic political popularity that enabled it to compete with the Conservative Party. Hopkins cites a letter from <a href="Edward%20Malet">Edward Malet</a>, the British consul general in Egypt at the time, to a member of the <a href="Second%20Gladstone%20ministry">Gladstone Cabinet</a> offering his congratulations on the invasion: "You have fought the battle of all Christendom and history will acknowledge it. May I also venture to say that it has given the Liberal Party a new lease of popularity and power." However, Dan Halvorson argues that the protection of the Suez Canal and British financial and trade interests were secondary and derivative. Instead, the primary motivation was the vindication of British prestige in both Europe and especially in India by suppressing the threat to “civilised” order posed by the Urabist revolt.
Egyptian independence.
In December 1921, the British authorities in Cairo imposed martial law and once again deported Zaghlul. Demonstrations again led to violence. In deference to the growing nationalism and at the suggestion of the <a href="High%20Commissioner">High Commissioner</a>, <a href="Lord%20Allenby">Lord Allenby</a>, the UK <a href="Unilateral%20Declaration%20of%20Egyptian%20Independence">unilaterally declared</a> Egyptian independence on 28 February 1922, abolishing the protectorate and establishing an independent <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Egypt">Kingdom of Egypt</a>. Until the <a href="Anglo-Egyptian%20treaty%20of%201936">Anglo-Egyptian treaty of 1936</a>, the Kingdom was only nominally independent, since the British retained control of foreign relations, communications, the military and the <a href="Anglo-Egyptian%20Sudan">Anglo-Egyptian Sudan</a>. Between 1936 and 1952, the British continued to maintain military presence and political advisors, at a reduced level.
During World War II, British troops <a href="Military%20history%20of%20Egypt%20during%20World%20War%20II">used Egypt</a> as a major base for Allied operations throughout the region. Egypt was nominally neutral in the war. 
British troops were withdrawn to the Suez Canal area in 1947, but nationalist, anti-British feelings continued to grow after the war. The <a href="Egyptian%20Revolution%20of%201952">Egyptian Revolution of 1952</a> overthrew the Egyptian monarchy, eliminated the British military presence in Egypt, and established the modern <a href="History%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20Egypt">Republic of Egypt</a>.
Suez Crisis of 1956.
In 1956, Egyptian president <a href="Gamal%20Abdel%20Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a> nationalized the <a href="Suez%20canal">Suez canal</a>, a vital waterway through which most of Europe's oil arrived from the Middle East. Britain and France, in league with Israel, invaded to seize the canal and overthrow Nasser. The United States, led by President <a href="Dwight%20D.%20Eisenhower">Dwight D. Eisenhower</a>, strenuously objected, using diplomatic and financial pressure to force the three invaders to withdraw. Prime Minister <a href="Anthony%20Eden">Anthony Eden</a> was humiliated and soon resigned. Thorpe summarized the unexpected results:
Eden's policy had four main aims: first, to secure the Suez Canal; second and consequently, to ensure continuity of oil supplies; third, to remove Nasser; and fourth, to keep the Russians out of the Middle East. The immediate consequence of the crisis was that the Suez Canal was blocked, oil supplies were interrupted, Nasser's position as the leader of Arab nationalism was strengthened, and the way was left open for Russian intrusion into the Middle East. It was a truly tragic end to his premiership, and one that came to assume a disproportionate importance in any assessment of his career."
Modern relations.
The relations also concern military business. Such as training, visits and access to the <a href="Commonwealth%20War%20Graves%20Commission">Commonwealth War Graves</a> in <a href="Heliopolis%20War%20Cemetery">Heliopolis</a> and <a href="El%20Alamein">El Alamein</a>. Also co-ordination over flights and <a href="Suez%20Canal">Suez Canal</a> transits for <a href="warship">warship</a>s.
According to the <a href="2001%20UK%20Census">2001 UK Census</a> some 24,700 Egyptian-born people were present in the UK. The <a href="Office%20for%20National%20Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> estimates that the equivalent figure for 2009 was 27,000.
In late 2014, the Egyptian-British Chamber of Commerce (EBCC) released a report detailing the trade volume between the two countries, which increased significantly that year. British exports to Egypt grew by 15%, while Egyptian exports to the UK grew by over 30%. The UK is the largest investor into the Egyptian economy, accounting for 41.3% of total <a href="foreign%20direct%20investment">foreign direct investment</a>. The <a href="New%20Suez%20Canal">New Suez Canal</a> project and Egypt's economic recovery following <a href="Egyptian%20Crisis%20%282011%E2%80%93present%29">three years of turmoil</a> since the 2011 uprising as contributing factors to this achievement.
Diplomatic missions.
Egypt's embassy in the United Kingdom is located at 26 <a href="South%20Audley%20Street">South Audley Street</a>, London W1K 1DW.
The United Kingdom's embassy in Egypt is located at 7 Ahmed Ragheb Street, Garden City, <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>. Outside Cairo, there is a British <a href="Consulate%20General">Consulate-General</a> in <a href="Alexandria%2C%20Egypt">Alexandria</a> and an <a href="Consul%20%28representative%29">Honorary Consulate</a> in <a href="Sharm%20el%20Sheik">Sharm el Sheik</a>.
The current <a href="List%20of%20Ambassadors%20of%20Egypt%20to%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Egyptian Ambassador to the UK</a> is <a href="Nasser%20Kamel">Nasser Kamel</a>, the <a href="List%20of%20diplomats%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom%20to%20Egypt">British Ambassador to Egypt</a> is Sir <a href="Geoffrey%20Adams">Geoffrey Adams</a>.
